Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Enabling Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) Fire Ignitions in Complex Firefighting Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Prescribed fire is critical for reducing catastrophic wildfires and sustaining healthy ecosystems. Yet the technology to support fire ignition and monitoring remains stagnant, risky, and expensive. This project aims to develop the Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) technology that can transform prescribed fire ignition and monitoring by: 1) enabling the communication between UASs and humans by sharing the vehicle intention through maneuvers, 2) improving UAS operation by taking into account operator availability, 3) leveraging the operator's knowledge to improve control of multiple vehicles, 4) fixing failures by enabling the operator and the system to work together, and 5) assessing the technological capabilities and associated users' acceptance of this technology. This effort is significant because it addresses unique co-robotic challenges in the UAS domain and is transformative in its potential to change how a range of organizations maintain their ecosystems and manage wildfires.

The project aims at developing and assessing techniques, tools, and systems to dramatically improve the potential for UASs to safely ignite and monitor fire. To achieve that goal, it conducts multidisciplinary work on: 1) motion-based languages that communicate UAS intention and knowledge to operators and bystanders, 2) co-regulation methodologies that incorporate operator availability and attention into traditional control and planning loops, 3) integrative functions that map the environmental knowledge and domain expertise of an operator into a fleet of vehicles to support different levels of autonomy, 4) co-debugging techniques from program analysis that collaborate with the operator to help diagnose and overcome failures caused by misconfigurations, and 5) cross-cutting studies to gain a better understanding of the attitudes of stakeholders towards UASs, and the features that are likely to promote stakeholder trust and acceptance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project pioneered the systems and algorithms to allow Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) to safely ignite prescribed fires from the air, leading to significant increases in safety and capabilities for firefighters. Fire is critical for reducing catastrophic wildfires and sustaining ecosystems. Yet the technology to support fire ignition and monitoring remains stagnant. Fire personnel operate under enduring risk in a rapidly evolving context, using drip torches to ignite fires. Alternative forms of support like trucks, helicopters, or planes are costly and often unavailable. While UASs have been used for fire monitoring, this project addressed several fundamental challenges in robotics to allow the UAS to safely ignite prescribed fires.


The intellectual merit of this project spanned robotics, computer science, fire ecology, and technology acceptance. To evaluate how UAS can interact with firefighters, we developed a taxonomy for characterizing flight path gestures that allow the UAS to convey states (e.g. about to start ignitions, landing, low battery) to operators and bystanders. We ran a number of studies and identified gestures that are easily recognizable from a range of angles. In addition, we developed intelligent control software that allows the user to select manual operation to fully autonomous operation and everything in between, allowing the users to dynamically adjust their workload. We examined the impact of software evolution and maintenance on controllers and built a software suite to assess those impacts. UAS that are operating in the challenging fire conditions must balance computational, motion, and sensing resources. To do this, we developed co-regulation strategies to optimize the allocation of these resources for both single robots and groups of UAS. 


The broader impact of this project has benefited a range of organizations and stakeholders by providing complementary technologies that fill a gap in fire monitoring and ignition and also by developing a rich understanding of attitudes towards UAS. We conducted a number of surveys and focus groups to understand attitudes and found that most people had positive views of using UAS for prescribed fires and trust in the technology. Further, the majority of respondents indicated a willingness to spend time on training to learn about and how to use new technologies. We evaluated and demonstrated the technologies developed with firefighters on a number of prescribed burns and in workshops and conferences. All of this has resulted in a highly capable aerial ignition system that can be used to ignite 100s of acres for prescribed burns and has now been licensed to a startup that has commercialized the UAS based aerial ignition system.
